resource.name: Crown Land
resource.description:
A spatial dataset of all Crown lands in Nova Scotia. Crown lands are all or any part of the land under the administration and control of the Minister of Natural Resources and Renewables as per the Crown Lands Act. The dataset includes land in which the Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources and Renewables has full or partial interest.
Data download also available via GeoNova: https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=87
Map service view also available via GeoNova: https://www.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnsgiwa.novascotia.ca%2Farcgis%2Frest%2Fservices%2FPLAN%2FPLANCrownLandsWM84V1%2FMapServer&source=sd

resource.name: Municipal Property Tax Rates
resource.description: The dataset is a list of property tax rates that are applicable in each municipality in the Province. These rates are applied to property assessment (based on market value) which can change from year to year. The convention is to express the tax rate as per $100 of assessment e.g., Amherst's residential rate is $1.63 per $100 of assessment.

domain_metadata.value: This information has been gathered from Statement of Estimate Reports as submitted to the Province by municipalities. The municipalities are required to submit this information to the Province by September 30th of each year.  Municipalities may also have additional area rates for special services on top of the general rate. Users are cautioned these tax rates are for general reference only, for official rates please contact the appropriate Municipality.   The Cape Breton Suburban rate is an average of 8 various rural suburban tax rates within the county of Cape Breton.    Effective April 1st, 2020, the Town of Windsor and the Municipality of West Hants have consolidated into a regional municipality, West Hants Regional Municipality. Please note, that the data for the West Hants Regional Municipality/Windsor/Hantsport  2020/2021 to 2022/2023 were amended on 2024-02-21.
Annually from each fiscal year, from 2009/2010 to 2024/2024 (April 1, 2009 to March 31, 2024)

resource.name: Queens County Current Data
resource.description: Current speed and direction time series data collected in a vertical profile at various locations throughout the coastal waters of Queens County.
columns_description: distance from the seafloor to the centre of the measurement bin (metres).
specific area where ADCP was deployed.
the depth of the ADCP below the surface (metres), measured by the ADCP sensor. Changes with the tide.

timestamp of the start of the ensemble (in UTC). Current speed and direction recorded at each timestamp are an average of many measurements recoded during the ensemble. See the “Nova Scotia Current Data Deployment Information” dataset for ensemble details for each deployment.

distance from the surface to the centre of the measurement bin (metres). Calculated as sensor_depth_below_surface_m + sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m - bin_height_above_sea_floor_m. See “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) for sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m.
waterbody in which the ADCP was deployed.

unique identifier for ADCP deployment. IDs are assigned incrementally by deployment date within a county. A skipped ID (e.g., consecutive IDs are XY001 and XY003) indicates that an ADCP was deployed but no useable current data were recovered (e.g., the battery failed).

direction of water flow for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (degrees). Measured travelling away from the ADCP sensor relative to True North (a reading of 90 degrees describes current travelling from west to east).
water speed for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (m / s).

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/b4qv-zmqj).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha). Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

resource.description: Oceanographic data from sensor strings deployed in Antigonish County as part of the Centre for Marine Applied Research's (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program.

Timestamp at which a measurement was made, in UTC. The formatting is "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS"
Temperature measurement, in degrees Celsius
Configuration in which the sensors were deployed. This can be one of six entries: “sub-surface buoy”, “surface buoy”, “attached to gear”, “attached to fixed structure”, “floating dock”, or “unknown”

Model of the sensor that recorded the measurement
Unique identifying number for the sensor that recorded the measurement

Salinity measurement, in practical salinity units

Quality control flag for temperature. Maximum flag value from three automated quality control tests: grossrange,  spike, and rolling_sd. Flag values can be:  "Pass",  "Not Evaluated", "Suspect/Of Interest", or "Fail"

Quality control flag for measured sensor depth. Maximum flag value from three automated quality control tests: grossrange,  spike, and rolling_sd. Flag values can be:  "Pass",  "Not Evaluated", "Suspect/Of Interest", or "Fail"

Quality control flag for salinity. Maximum flag value from three automated quality control tests: grossrange,  spike, and rolling_sd. Flag values can be:  "Pass",  "Not Evaluated", "Suspect/Of Interest", or "Fail"

Quality control flag for dissolved oxygen (mg/L). Maximum flag value from four automated quality control tests: grossrange, climatology, spike, and rolling_sd. Flag values can be:  "Pass",  "Not Evaluated", "Suspect/Of Interest", or "Fail"

Depth of the sensor, as measured by the sensor in metres
Longitude of the deployment (decimal degrees)
Aquaculture lease number associated with the station (where applicable)
Latitude of the deployment (decimal degrees)
Dissolved oxygen measurement, in units of mg/L, without applying a salinity correction factor
Dissolved oxygen measurement, in units of percent saturation
Quality control flag for sensor depth at low tide. Flag values can be "Pass",  "Not Evaluated", "Suspect/Of Interest", or "Fail". The same flag is applied to the whole deployment.
String describing the instrument deployment and retrieval dates. The format is "YYYY-MMM-DD to YYYY-MMM-DD"

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research’s (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program provides high resolution data on ocean variables from around the coast of Nova Scotia. The program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in the early 1990s. In 2019, CMAR assumed responsibility for the program and expanded its scope and mandate. Through the Water Quality Branch of the program, CMAR collects temperature, dissolved oxygen, and salinity data using sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or grappling methods. Automated Quality Control tests have been applied to the data to identify outlying and unexpected observations. The results of these tests are summarized in the “qc_flag” columns of the dataset. Each data point is assigned a flag value of “Pass”, “Suspect/Of Interest”, “Fail”, or “Not Evaluated”. Observations flagged as “Pass” passed all tests and can be included in analyses. Dissolved oxygen observations flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” likely indicate biofouling signals and should be excluded from analysis or used with extreme caution. Observations for other variables flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” should be reviewed before being included in analyses. Observations flagged as “Fail” should be excluded from most analyses. Some tests cannot be applied to certain observations, which will be flagged as “Not Evaluated”. These observations can typically be included in analyses. Flags should be used as a guide only, and data users are responsible for evaluating the quality of the data prior to use in any analysis. For more information about the Quality Control tests, visit the CMAR Data Governance website (https://dempsey-cmar.github.io/cmp-data-governance/pages/cmp_about.html). The Coastal Monitoring Program Water Quality data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends filtering the data to the waterbody, station, depth, quality control flag, and/or time period of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/d6fb-k8yz). The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on this Portal shows additional locations with available Water Quality data collected through CMAR’s Coastal Monitoring Program (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. If you have accessed any Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform. Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data. Contact info@cmar.ca for more information.

resource.name: Nominee Certificates Issued by Stream
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Certificates are issued in particular streams of the Nominee Program, and each stream has different eligibility criteria. Over time, streams may close as new streams are developed. This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by the streams under which the nomination was made.

See https://novascotiaimmigration.com/move-here/ for information on current streams.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: A nomination certificate may represent one or more people. Each nomination certificate issued includes the principal applicant and any family members (spouse and dependents) expected to accompany them to Canada.

resource.name: Uniform Assessment
resource.description: One measure of a municipality's financial health is its own-source revenue base as represented by the total uniform assessment. This figure is the total of the taxable property assessment plus the value of grants municipality receives from special property tax arrangements.

Overall results are provided for each question and results are presented by demographic markers (age, gender, geographic region, education level and household income).

resource.name: Municipal Land Use Planning Comprehensiveness
resource.description:
This dataset provides information about the extent of municipal land use planning in Nova Scotia. Each municipality is listed along with the type of its land use planning described as either comprehensive for entire municipality, comprehensive for local areas only, comprehensive for towns, or single issue.  It also lists the date of the municipal land use plans described. 

A comprehensive strategy is one that address all major areas of concern, for example: residential, commercial, industrial, recreational, environmental, social and economic. A single-issue plan only deals with specific land-use issues such as wind turbines, drinking water protection, general development. Municipal planning strategies may be developed for an entire municipality and/or a local area within its jurisdiction.

resource.name: Age of Nominees at Time of Application
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa.

Nominees must generally be between the ages of 21 to 55 at time of application, but the LSI reserves the right to waive this criteria in exceptional circumstances. This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by age range. 

The maximum number of certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction. Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column. The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Fishing-and-Aquaculture/Antigonish-County-Daily-Average-Current-Speed-by-D/dxk4-auk4). Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research’s (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program provides high resolution data on ocean variables from around the coast of Nova Scotia. The program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in the early 1990s. In 2019, CMAR assumed responsibility for the program and expanded its scope and mandate. Through the Water Quality Branch of the program, CMAR collects temperature, dissolved oxygen, and salinity data using sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or grappling methods. Automated Quality Control tests have been applied to the data to identify outlying and unexpected observations. The results of these tests are summarized in the “qc_flag” columns of the dataset. Each data point is assigned a flag value of “Pass”, “Suspect/Of Interest”, “Fail”, or “Not Evaluated”. Observations flagged as “Pass” passed all tests and can be included in analyses. Dissolved oxygen observations flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” likely indicate biofouling signals and should be excluded from analysis or used with extreme caution. Observations for other variables flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” should be reviewed before being included in analyses. Observations flagged as “Fail” should be excluded from most analyses. Some tests cannot be applied to certain observations, which will be flagged as “Not Evaluated”. These observations can typically be included in analyses. Flags should be used as a guide only, and data users are responsible for evaluating the quality of the data prior to use in any analysis. For more information about the Quality Control tests, visit the CMAR Data Governance website (https://dempsey-cmar.github.io/cmp-data-governance/pages/cmp_about.html). The Coastal Monitoring Program Water Quality data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends filtering the data to the waterbody, station, depth, quality control flag, and/or time period of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/5ech-4c5t). The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on this Portal shows additional locations with available Water Quality data collected through CMAR’s Coastal Monitoring Program (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. If you have accessed any Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform. Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data. Contact info@cmar.ca for more information.

We respond to all complaint submissions and submission of a complaint does not necessarily confirm non-compliance on the part of a business. We educate and assist consumers with complaints about the industries we regulate and license, and are pleased to provide education and other sources of help if the complaint falls outside SNS Consumer Protection legislation. Program responsibility for a number of the listed categories falls outside SNS. Although we collect this information, complaints may be registered through other departments, agencies, and organizations which would not be captured in this data. . SNS continues to seek to modernize the way complaints are registered to improve data collection and classification.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

domain_metadata.value: Data are current as of April 1, 2024 (when data for 2023 onward were updated as necessary). Data are extracted from a live database environment and are provisional and subject to change. Some case investigations in recent years remain ongoing. NS totals may be greater than sum of zones, as totals include cases from out of province and a small proportion where location of residence is under investigation.  Data include NSMES cases for which manner of death was determined to be suicide and recorded as suicide on the Medical Certificate of Death by the Medical Examiner.   Data for recent months and for the previous year are preliminary and counts and associated rates are likely to increase as case investigations are completed. Case review found that >90% of suicide deaths excluding those caused by drug toxicity were certified post-autopsy, which occurs within days of a reported death. Acccordingly, monitoring of suicide excluding drug toxicity provides a largely accurate, timely indicator of non-drug toxicity suicide. As such, counts of deaths by suicide excluding drug toxicity deaths is provided in addition to counts of total suicide deaths. Indicators of probable and confirmed drug toxicity deaths (including accident and suicide deaths) are also available on the data.novascotia.ca site for concurrent monitoring.  Data provided here may differ from Vital Statistics data sources due to differences in reporting timeframes (e.g. a death certified as suicide may appear under the 'not elsewhere classified' classification if the death was not certified by the time of data submission for a particular report.  Geocoding of address data has resulted in reclassification of zone of residence for a small number of cases (compared to prior releases of data). Population data have been updated with the most recent available data from Statistics Canada (17-10-0134-01; rate data may differ slightly from previous releases).

resource.name: Marriage Bonds 1763-1864; Marriage Registrations 1864-1946
resource.description: Civil registration of marriages in Nova Scotia began in 1758, with the introduction of procedures for obtaining a marriage license. The license was optional, surviving records are incomplete, and 'calling the banns' remained the preferred procedure for formalizing the marriage ritual. The parallel custom of posting a Marriage Bond, in addition to taking out a license, also dates from this early period. The bond was an optional adjunct which served to indicate the absence of legal impediments to the intended marriage; an incomplete series of these bonds exists for the years 1763-1864. Mandatory civil registration of marriages began in 1864 and has continued since, although compliance was not universal throughout the province until the early 20th century.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Minimum Wage
resource.description: Provincial regulations establish the province’s minimum wage. Minimum wage is the lowest legal wage employers can pay their employees. This dataset includes minimum wage rates in Nova Scotia dating back to 2002. Employers, employees and the public request minimum wage data, including in relation to historical rates.

domain_metadata.value: Between 1958 and 1965, minimum wage was set at a weekly - rather than hourly - rate and was based on where the work was performed (provincial zones). From 1965 to 1971, hourly minimum wages rates were set based on age, experience, sex and provincial zones. From 1972 until 1992 hourly minimum wage rates were set based on age and experience. Starting in 1993, age was removed as a factor in setting the minimum wage, which resulted in experienced and inexperienced rates being set until  April 1, 2020 when the inexperienced rate was eliminated leaving just one minimum wage rate.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Examination Results by year and board - Français 10
resource.description: Provides examination results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year examination has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the examinations.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 28, 2021. Assessments were not administered for 2016-2017 school year. French (CSAP) program students enrolled in Français 10 courses write this examination in January or June. French Immersion students do not write this examination.  For the reading portion, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. Students also completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this examination and to set the expectation of the examination. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do at the end of the course. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

resource.name: NS Provincial Gaming Activity
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Alcohol, Gaming, Fuel and Tobacco Division is responsible for the regulation of legal gaming in the province of Nova Scotia.  These gaming activities include:
i.             Atlantic Lottery Corporation products (ALC), 
ii.            Casino Nova Scotia (Casino),
iii.           charitable bingo (Bingo),
iv.           charitable ticket lotteries (Lotteries), and 
v.            video lottery terminals (VLT).

domain_metadata.value: This information is reported in the Annual Gaming Report prepared by the Alcohol, Gaming, Fuel and Tobacco Division of Service Nova Scotia, and posted on the AGFT website at http://novascotia.ca/sns/access/alcohol-gaming/publications.asp

For the purpose of measuring the volume of gaming activities on a consistent basis, the Alcohol, Gaming, Fuel and Tobacco Division uses the “wager” as a base unit, presented in thousands of dollars ($ thousands).  This figure represents the amount of money (rounded to the nearest  thousand dollar)  actually wagered on each gaming activity before prizes are awarded, operating expenses are deducted, and other assorted expenditures are accounted for.  The wager for each type of gaming activity is defined in the following manner: cash deposited when referring to VLTs; cash deposited and value of tickets inserted into casino slot machines plus the chips purchased for table games when referring to casinos; cash paid for the purchase of bingo cards when referring to bingo; and cash paid for the purchase of tickets when referring to ticket lotteries. In October 2023, erroneous 2021-22 fiscal year casino figures (Casino Total and Prizes) were updated in the dataset. Discrepancy between the public dataset and the 2021-22 Gaming Report figures will be addressed in the 2022-23 report.

resource.name: NS Correctional Services Expenditures
resource.description: The financial expenditures of Correctional Services is an indicator of the resources required to administer custodial and community-based sentences in the province. This dataset provides financial information such as the gross expenditures on Nova Scotia Corrections; the per capita expenditures on Nova Scotia Corrections, which is calculated using the total population in Nova Scotia; and the average daily cost in adult custody in Nova Scotia, which is calculated using the adult offender population in adult facilities. Fluctuations in the cost of Corrections may be driven by a number of factors, including but not limited to: the level of crime, legislative and policy responses to crime, sentencing practices, and administrative changes relating to organizational structure and the delivery of services, as well as changes in salaries and benefits for staff. The source for the financial information is the Nova Scotia Department of Justice, Financial Services Corporate Service Unit (CSU). Population data is sourced from Statistics Canada CANSIM Table 051-0005 - Estimates of population, Canada, provinces and territories.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of September 8, 2023. Prior to 2008-09, the province reported on net operational expenditures rather than gross operational expenditures in the departmental accountability report.

resource.name: Ecological Land Classification (ELC) - 2015
resource.description: The Ecological Land Classification (ELC version 2015) for Nova Scotia provides a hierarchical mapping of the province's forest ecosystems into ecosections, ecodistricts and ecoregions. It includes interpretation of the dominant natural disturbance regimes and potential climax forests at the ecosection level.

domain_metadata.value: The Department of Natural Resources and Renewables has prepared the 2015 version of the ELC to assist in the planning and management of sustainable forests. In this framework of mapped ecosystems the ELC provides an understanding of ecosystem form and function and the dependent biodiversity by linking the physical and biological environment of each system. Ecosystems on the landscape represent the effects of the interactions of climate, landform, water and soils and thus the distribution of biodiversity. Land Systems are mapped at 1:50,000 from the Nova Scotia Biophysical Land Classification were used to define the physical attributes of the smallest mapped unit of the ELC - the Ecosection (1:50,000). Infrared aerial photography (1:63,560) flown in 1976 and used to determine the Land Systems was also used to re-check Ecosection boundaries. In addition the following were used to assist in the delineation of Ecosections, Ecodistricts and Ecoregions: Provincial soils maps - 1:50,000; 1:63,000; 1:126,000 Surficial geology maps - 1:500,000; 1:100,000 National topographic series - 1:50,000 Forestry mapping - 1:10,000 Geology - 1:640,000 Radarsat 3D imagery The Climate for Agriculture in Canada (1985) The Natural History of Nova Scotia (1996) Geological Background and Physiography of Nova Scotia (1982) A National Ecological Framework for Canada (1995) Ecoregions and Ecodistricts of Nova Scotia (1999) Natural Landscapes of Nova Scotia (1997) This edition includes updates of the 2005 and 2007 editions to incorporate more recent data and understanding as of 2015.
Based on data available and understanding as of 2015

resource.name: Invest Nova Scotia Venture Capital Investments
resource.description:
Invest Nova Scotia is Nova Scotia’s business development agency that works to promote economic growth and community economic development in the province by enabling business, innovation, sustainability and entrepreneurship. 

Early stage deep technology start-ups are a key focus area for Invest Nova Scotia. They are supported through venture capital, incubation facilities, expert advice, and other acceleration initiatives.

Invest Nova Scotia makes equity investments through the Nova Scotia First Fund (NSFF), a venture capital fund backed by the Nova Scotia government. Venture capital-backed start-ups typically have a greater economic impact than their non-backed peers, demonstrating stronger growth in revenue, employment and assets. Invest Nova Scotia is driven by generating financial returns on its fund, and also seeks to leverage its deals with other venture capital and angel co-investors, attracting new capital and expertise for the region.

This dataset lists the companies Invest Nova Scotia invested in and the amount invested.

resource.name: Invest Nova Scotia Incubation Resident Companies
resource.description:
Invest Nova Scotia is Nova Scotia’s business development agency that works to promote economic growth and community economic development in the province by enabling business, innovation, sustainability and entrepreneurship. 

Early stage deep technology start-ups are a key focus area for Invest Nova Scotia. They are supported through venture capital, incubation facilities, expert advice, and other acceleration initiatives.

The Bays at Invest Nova Scotia in Dartmouth targets companies in clean technology and a variety of other knowledge-based sectors, and offers a reliable enterprise-grade voice and data network, redundant high-speed internet services, and a dependable server hosting facility. The Labs at Invest Nova Scotia in Halifax focuses on companies in the life sciences industry and offers specialized scientific infrastructure otherwise unavailable in the commercial real estate market. The Start-Up Yard incubation facility at the Centre for Ocean Ventures & Entrepreneurship (COVE) helps early stage companies commercialize their ocean technologies and succeed in the global marketplace.

This dataset lists the resident companies at Invest Nova Scotia’s three incubation facilities.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of June 9, 2023. Some of Invest Nova Scotia's incubation resident companies take space at the facilities for just a short time (i.e., six-months) as their residency is part of an Invest Nova Scotia program (e.g., Start-Up Visa Program, Accelerate Program).

resource.name: Citizenship of Nominees
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Applicants are attracted to the Nova Scotia Nominee Program from around the world. This dataset provides the number of nomination certificates issued annually by citizenship of the applicant. 

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research’s (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program provides high resolution data on ocean variables from around the coast of Nova Scotia. The program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in the early 1990s. In 2019, CMAR assumed responsibility for the program and expanded its scope and mandate. Through the Water Quality Branch of the program, CMAR collects temperature, dissolved oxygen, and salinity data using sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or grappling methods. Automated Quality Control tests have been applied to the data to identify outlying and unexpected observations. The results of these tests are summarized in the “qc_flag” columns of the dataset. Each data point is assigned a flag value of “Pass”, “Suspect/Of Interest”, “Fail”, or “Not Evaluated”. Observations flagged as “Pass” passed all tests and can be included in analyses. Dissolved oxygen observations flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” likely indicate biofouling signals and should be excluded from analysis or used with extreme caution. Observations for other variables flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” should be reviewed before being included in analyses. Observations flagged as “Fail” should be excluded from most analyses. Some tests cannot be applied to certain observations, which will be flagged as “Not Evaluated”. These observations can typically be included in analyses. Flags should be used as a guide only, and data users are responsible for evaluating the quality of the data prior to use in any analysis. For more information about the Quality Control tests, visit the CMAR Data Governance website (https://dempsey-cmar.github.io/cmp-data-governance/pages/cmp_about.html). The Coastal Monitoring Program Water Quality data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends filtering the data to the waterbody, station, depth, quality control flag, and/or time period of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/twbe-dv9i). The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on this Portal shows additional locations with available Water Quality data collected through CMAR’s Coastal Monitoring Program (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. If you have accessed any Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform. Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data. Contact info@cmar.ca for more information.

resource.name: Film Industry Tax Credit – Approved Tax Credits
resource.description: Public record for the Film Industry Tax Credit containing information from approved Part A and Part B applications across all corporations. Information includes company name, parent company name, production title, application type (Part A or B), amount of credit provided (or sought if Part A), approval date.
columns_name:
Amount of Credit Provided 
(or Sought if Part A)

domain_metadata.value: The Film Industry Tax Credit is phased out so this dataset switched to one-time in August 2023. Productions are added to the list after a Part A / Part B application is approved. Part A applications, which are not mandatory, determine whether a production is eligible for the tax credit and uses the production's budget to calculate an estimated tax credit amount the corporation may receive. Part B applications are mandatory and determine whether a production is eligible for the tax credit and uses actual spending to calculate a tax credit amount. Once a Part B application is approved, a tax credit certificate is issued and the corporation can claim the tax credit on their corporate income tax return. The Film Industry Tax Credit has been replaced by the Digital Animation Tax Credit and the Nova Scotia Film & Television Production Incentive Fund.

domain_metadata.value: Understanding Climate Change Impacts in Relation to Wellbeing for Nova Scotia, available at https://climatechange.novascotia.ca/climate-impacts

The projections include 88 individual climate indices for each region, with results presented for two emissions scenarios (RCP4.5 and RCP8.5), four averaged 30-year time periods (1981-2010, 2015-2045, 2035-2065, and 2065-2095, denoted in the data by their end year), and three different percentiles for each to show the model range (p05, p50, and p95). For example, the column "rcp45 p05 2010" displays results for the RCP4.5 scenario, for the fifth percentile (p05) of the multi-model ensemble, for the 1981-2010 time period. This information was generated through an ensemble of 27 climate models as part of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)’s Coupled Model Intercomparison Project 5 (CMIP5), with the data statistically downscaled for Canada by the Pacific Climate Impacts Consortium (PCIC) using the BCCAQv2 method (downloaded from https://data.pacificclimate.org/portal/downscaled_gcms/map/ in December 2019), with index calculations completed using the Climpact2 tool on behalf of the Province of Nova Scotia. Full methodology, including the list of the 27 models used and additional details on climate indices, can be found in Appendix B of the 2022 Nova Scotia climate change risk assessment report: http://climatechange.novascotia.ca

domain_metadata.value: French program (CSAP) Grade 8 students write this assessment in June. Students answered questions in each of the mathematics strands (le nombre; les régularités et les relations; la mesure et la géométrie; et les statistiques et les probabilités). Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) and Level 4 (above the expectation).Students also received a scaled score in mathematics (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800).  Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this assessment and to set the performance expectation, which is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the end of grade 8. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/e9p6-as65).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha). Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

resource.name: Amount Raised by Invest Nova Scotia Investment Portfolio Companies
resource.description:
Invest Nova Scotia is Nova Scotia’s business development agency that works to promote economic growth and community economic development in the province by enabling business, innovation, sustainability and entrepreneurship. 

Early stage deep technology start-ups are a key focus area for Invest Nova Scotia. They are supported through venture capital, incubation facilities, expert advice, and other acceleration initiatives.

Invest Nova Scotia makes equity investments through the Nova Scotia First Fund (NSFF), a venture capital fund backed by the Nova Scotia government. Venture capital-backed start-ups typically have a greater economic impact than their non-backed peers, demonstrating stronger growth in revenue, employment and assets. Invest Nova Scotia is driven by generating financial returns on its fund, and also seeks to leverage its deals with other venture capital and angel co-investors, attracting new capital and expertise for the region.

The Amount Raised by Invest Nova Scotia Investment Portfolio Companies dataset shows the total investment dollars raised by Invest Nova Scotia’s investment portfolio throughout the year. The amount speaks to the strength of the companies in Invest Nova Scotia’s portfolio (i.e., their ability to attract capital) and Invest Nova Scotia’s ability to support them in those efforts.
columns_name: Amount raised by Innovacorp portfolio compaies

resource.name: Hand Hygiene – Hand Washing Rates for Healthcare Workers
resource.description: Hand Hygiene rates represents the hand washing rates for healthcare workers within the Nova Scotia Health Authority and the IWK.  The rates are collected and reported to quarterly by hygiene auditors who are trained hospital staff.  The rates for healthcare workers who clean their hands before initial contact with a patient and/or patient environment and the rates for after contact with the patient and/or patient environment are reported publicly and included in this dataset. Proper hand hygiene is one of the most important means to preventing the spread of germs which can cause infections. This dataset lists the hand hygiene rates that are reported publicly by the Department of Health and Wellness. Data fields include: Year, Quarter, Zone, Before Initial Contact, After Contact.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research’s (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program provides high resolution data on ocean variables from around the coast of Nova Scotia. The program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in the early 1990s. In 2019, CMAR assumed responsibility for the program and expanded its scope and mandate. Through the Water Quality Branch of the program, CMAR collects temperature, dissolved oxygen, and salinity data using sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or grappling methods. Automated Quality Control tests have been applied to the data to identify outlying and unexpected observations. The results of these tests are summarized in the “qc_flag” columns of the dataset. Each data point is assigned a flag value of “Pass”, “Suspect/Of Interest”, “Fail”, or “Not Evaluated”. Observations flagged as “Pass” passed all tests and can be included in analyses. Dissolved oxygen observations flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” likely indicate biofouling signals and should be excluded from analysis or used with extreme caution. Observations for other variables flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” should be reviewed before being included in analyses. Observations flagged as “Fail” should be excluded from most analyses. Some tests cannot be applied to certain observations, which will be flagged as “Not Evaluated”. These observations can typically be included in analyses. Flags should be used as a guide only, and data users are responsible for evaluating the quality of the data prior to use in any analysis. For more information about the Quality Control tests, visit the CMAR Data Governance website (https://dempsey-cmar.github.io/cmp-data-governance/pages/cmp_about.html). The Coastal Monitoring Program Water Quality data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends filtering the data to the waterbody, station, depth, quality control flag, and/or time period of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/chb4-suz2). The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on this Portal shows additional locations with available Water Quality data collected through CMAR’s Coastal Monitoring Program (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. If you have accessed any Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform. Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data. Contact info@cmar.ca for more information.

domain_metadata.value: Understanding Climate Change Impacts in Relation to Wellbeing for Nova Scotia, available at https://climatechange.novascotia.ca/climate-impacts

Sea level rise projections for the province of Nova Scotia and its 18 individual census divisions (counties). Results are presented for two emissions scenarios (RCP4.5 and RCP8.5), four time periods (1981-2010, 2015-2045, 2035-2065, and 2065-2095), and three different percentiles for each to show the model range (p05, p50, and p95). The time periods were calculated by fitting a linear trend to the 31-year periods and taking the average, so 2065-2095 equates to the expected SLR in 2080 (representing the middle year of each time period). The maximum, mean, and minimum values for each region represent the statistics for different locations within each county (e.g., for Annapolis, looking at RCP8.5 p50 in 2080, anticipated sea level rise is between 55.7-58.3 cm depending where in the county you are). Sea level rise projections were developed for Canada by James et al. (Geological Survey of Canada, 2021, Open File 8764). This information incorporates the most recent sea level projections from IPCC AR5 (Church et al., 2013a) which includes contributions from glaciers and thermo-steric expansion of the ocean. The local contributions to sea level rise associated with glacial isostatic adjustment were updated with the NAD83v70VG vertical land motion (Robin et al., 2020).  Sea level projections are relative to the average sea level over the base period 1986-2005. Full methodology can be found in Appendix B of the 2022 Nova Scotia climate change risk assessment report: http://climatechange.novascotia.ca

resource.name: Nova Scotia Topographic DataBase - Buildings (Poly Layer)
resource.description:
Part of the Nova Scotia Topographic Database (NSTDB), the buildings theme layer is updated and maintained from aerial photography. Buildings over 30m (one side) are collected as polygons, all others as points. Selected buildings are inspected in the field or interpreted from aerial photography and classified according to use such as hospitals, schools, police stations or community centres. Building feature codes and their descriptions are provided with the download in a NSTDB feature code table.
Data download also available via GeoNova: https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=20

resource.name: [ARCHIVED] Select Nova Scotia
resource.description: [ARCHIVED] The Select Nova Scotia program has ended and the data contained in this dataset is no longer being collected. Select Nova Scotia is a program developed by the Province of Nova Scotia to encourage Nova Scotians to shop and buy locally. Select Nova Scotia promotions and campaigns and the web site raise consumer awareness about Nova Scotia agri-food and seafood products, and other locally made goods.

domain_metadata.value: Archived on May 27, 2022. The Select Nova Scotia program has ended and the data contained in this dataset is no longer being collected. Much of the information is from businesses that have registered, self-identified as producers and sellers of local food, craft and artisan products.  However, the orignial web site was populated from an existing database. Some errors and inaccuracies are still present in both the old dataset and newly registered. If businesses are not diligent about updating their profile, errors may exist.  We will be requiring all current members to update their profile yearly, and will be removing profiles that do not meet our newly instated web site guidelines: To be eligible to register on the Select Nova Scotia website, your business must: have its head office in Nova Scotia; produce, harvest or sell Nova Scotia products; if a restaurant, be a member in good standing of Taste of Nova Scotia.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Reading and Writing in Grade 8
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 28, 2021. Assessments were not administered for 2016-2017 school year. English program Grade 8 students, including French Immersion, write this assessment in June. For the reading portion of the assessment, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. For the writing portion of the assessment, students completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to build this assessment, score the writing tasks and set the performance expectations in Reading and Writing. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the end of grade 8. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

resource.description: This information is taken from pedestrian counters placed along the Halifax Waterfront at the following locations: Boardwalk North (44.6512 N, 63.57267 W), Cable Plaza (44.64897 N 63.57134 W), Summit Boardwalk (44.64671 N 63.56991 W), and Bishop’s Landing Boardwalk (44.64482 N 63.56817 W). domain_metadata.value: The counters add up each person who walks past, which means the numbers do not represent unique visitation. The numbers in the data represent the totals for each month. resource.name: Events East Group Economic Impact
resource.description: This data set provides economic impact from two of Events East Group business groups: Halifax Convention Centre and Scotiabank Centre.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of October 25, 2023. All direct expenditures associated with Halifax Convention Centre are considered incremental. 27 per cent of Scotiabank Centre direct expenditures are incremental. Where there are missing values, the data is not available. With the transition to a new governance structure combined with operating both the World Trade and Convention Centre (WTCC) and the new Halifax Convention Centre during the fiscal year, 2017-18 represents an anomaly for the organization and is not comparable to past operations or indicative of future years. Events East Group began managing all operations of the former Trade Centre Limited (TCL) effective April 1, 2017, however, the financial cutover to Events East was triggered by achievement of substantial completion of the Halifax Convention Centre, which did not take place until March 1, 2018. For this reason, comparatives between Halifax Convention Centre and Convention Centre are not applicable.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research’s (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program provides high resolution data on ocean variables from around the coast of Nova Scotia. The program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in the early 1990s. In 2019, CMAR assumed responsibility for the program and expanded its scope and mandate. Through the Water Quality Branch of the program, CMAR collects temperature, dissolved oxygen, and salinity data using sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or grappling methods. Automated Quality Control tests have been applied to the data to identify outlying and unexpected observations. The results of these tests are summarized in the “qc_flag” columns of the dataset. Each data point is assigned a flag value of “Pass”, “Suspect/Of Interest”, “Fail”, or “Not Evaluated”. Observations flagged as “Pass” passed all tests and can be included in analyses. Dissolved oxygen observations flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” likely indicate biofouling signals and should be excluded from analysis or used with extreme caution. Observations for other variables flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” should be reviewed before being included in analyses. Observations flagged as “Fail” should be excluded from most analyses. Some tests cannot be applied to certain observations, which will be flagged as “Not Evaluated”. These observations can typically be included in analyses. Flags should be used as a guide only, and data users are responsible for evaluating the quality of the data prior to use in any analysis. For more information about the Quality Control tests, visit the CMAR Data Governance website (https://dempsey-cmar.github.io/cmp-data-governance/pages/cmp_about.html). The Coastal Monitoring Program Water Quality data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends filtering the data to the waterbody, station, depth, quality control flag, and/or time period of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/5p9y-iyag). The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on this Portal shows additional locations with available Water Quality data collected through CMAR’s Coastal Monitoring Program (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. If you have accessed any Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform. Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data. Contact info@cmar.ca for more information.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Lake Chemistry Data
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Lake Survey program is a partnership initiative between the Department of Environment and Climate Change and the Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture to inventory lakes throughout the province determining baseline water quality, in support of both sport fisheries and water resource management areas.

The following weblink connects to a Department of Environment and Climate Change web map that includes the locations of the monitored lakes within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same lake chemistry dataset: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd"

domain_tags: lakes; water bodies; chemistry; water resources management; fish; water quality

domain_metadata.value: Water quality samples are collected at approximately 10 different lakes per annum. The samples are submitted to the Nova Scotia Environmental Services Laboratory operated by the Nova Scotia Health Authority in Halifax, NS for analysis. Field parameters are measured using a multiparameter instrument. The following are the monitored water quality parameters and applicable measurement units: field temperature (°C), field dissolved oxygen (mg/L), Secchi disc depth (m), select metals (µg/L), calcium (mg/L), magnesium (mg/L), hardness as CaCO3 (mg/L), lab conductivity (umho/cm), lab pH (-), lab turbidity (-), alkalinity as CaCO3 (mg/L), chloride (mg/L), colour (TCU), silica (mg/L), sulphate (mg/L), total nitrogen (mg/L), nitrate and nitrite as N (mg/L), ammonia as N (mg/L), orthophosphorus as P, (mg/L), total phosphorus (mg/L), total suspended solids (mg/L), total organic carbon (mg/L), chlorophyll a (mg/m3) and pheophytin (µg/L).  Bathymetric maps have been produced for most of the sampled lakes and their attributes (surface area, volume, max & mean depths) are included in the dataset.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Reading and Writing in Grade 3
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of March 5, 2018. English program Grade 3 students write this assessment on two days in late September/early October. French Immersion students do not write this assessment. For the reading portion of the assessment, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. Individual student results were reported in three levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), and Level 3 and above (at or above the expectation). For the writing portion of the assessment, students completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800).  Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to build this assessment, score the writing tasks and set the performance expectations in Reading and Writing. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the beginning of grade 3. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

resource.name: Ecological Land Classification (ELC) – 2007 (Historical)
resource.description: For most recent Ecological Land Classification data, see: https://data.novascotia.ca/d/q6zd-39t3 The Ecological Land Classification (ELC) for Nova Scotia provides a hierarchical mapping of the province's forest ecosystems into ecosections, ecodistricts and ecoregions. It includes interpretation of the dominant natural disturbance regimes and potential climax forests at the ecosection level.

domain_metadata.value: For most recent Ecological Land Classification data, see: https://data.novascotia.ca/d/q6zd-39t3. The Department of Natural Resources and Renewables has prepared the ELC to assist in the planning and management of sustainable forests. In this framework of mapped ecosystems the ELC provides an understanding of ecosystem form and function and the dependent biodiversity by linking the physical and biological environment of each system. Ecosystems on the landscape represent the effects of the interactions of climate, landform, water and soils and thus the distribution of biodiversity. Land Systems are mapped at 1:50,000 from the Nova Scotia Biophysical Land Classification were used to define the physical attributes of the smallest mapped unit of the ELC - the Ecosection (1:50,000). Infrared aerial photography (1:63,560) flown in 1976 and used to determine the Land Systems was also used to re-check Ecosection boundaries. In addition the following were used to assist in the delineation of Ecosections, Ecodistricts and Ecoregions: Provincial soils maps - 1:50,000; 1:63,000; 1:126,000. Surficial geology maps - 1:500,000; 1:100,000. National topographic series - 1:50,000. Forestry mapping - 1:10,000. Geology - 1:640,000. Radarsat 3D imagery. The Climate for Agriculture in Canada (1985). The Natural History of Nova Scotia (1996). Geological Background and Physiography of Nova Scotia (1982). A National Ecological Framework for Canada (1995). Ecoregions and Ecodistricts of Nova Scotia (1999). Natural Landscapes of Nova Scotia (1997). This edition includes updates of the 2005 edition to coordinate with the Ecological Landscape Analysis (ELA) results that are included as attributes.
Based on data available and understanding as of 2007

resource.name: Crime Statistics - Crime Severity Index
resource.description: The dataset includes crime statistics at the provincial and police service levels. It is based on police reported incidents of crime reported through the Uniform Crime Reporting Survey (UCR). Statistics include the crime severity index, violent crime severity index, and non-violent crime severity index overall for provincial and police service levels. The Youth Crime Severity Index is based on the same principles as the overall Crime Severity Index, which reflects the seriousness of offences, but uses the number of youths accused instead of an incident count. Statistics included are: youth crime severity index, youth violent crime severity index and youth non-violent crime severity index for provincial level data only. This data is sourced from Statistics Canada through CANSIM.

domain_metadata.value: CANSIM Table 252-0075 Incident-based crime statistics, by detailed violations and police services, Atlantic provinces (http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/a26?lang=eng&id=2520075); CANSIM Table 252-0083 Crime severity index and weighted clearance rates, by police services, Atlantic provinces (http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/a26?lang=eng&id=2520083)

Current as of August 30, 2023. 1) The Crime Severity Index is calculated using the Incident-based Uniform Crime Reporting Survey (UCR2) data. 2) The Youth Crime Severity Index is based on the same principles as the Overall Crime Severity Index, which reflects the relative seriousness of different offences, but uses the number of youths accused instead of an incident count. 3) During the production of each year's crime statistics, data from the previous year are revised to reflect any updates or changes that have been received from the police services. 4) The crime severity index includes all Criminal Code violations including traffic, as well as drug violations and all Federal Statutes. 5) The violent crime severity index includes all Incident-based Uniform Crime Reporting Survey (UCR2) violent violations. 6) The non-violent crime severity index includes all non-violent Criminal Code violations including traffic, as well as drug violations and all Federal Statutes 7) Where data is unavailable, the cell has been marked by "..".
